posts.cooked:
Don’t know if this has been discussed already, but fyi from a recent new string:

Usernames on Signal are optional. If you choose to create a username other Signal users will be able to find you by this username and contact you without knowing your phone number.

link_counts.title: Signal Needs to Shift to a Focus on Privacy/Anonymity
Is there confusion of "usernames" vs. "phone number privacy" and if so, how can it be avoided?
Signal Blog: Removing SMS support from Signal Android (very soon)
Limit who can be added to groups
Limit who can be added to groups
Mandatory PIN without clear explanation within the app might cause significant number of users to quit using Signal
The uncertainty caused by the coronavirus gives Signal an opportunity to gain a new load of conscious users. But is Signal ready?

Kik Messenger shuts down (no longer true)

posts.cooked:
You spilled our secret, hopefully its this:

Secondary user ID alongside phone number Feature Requests
I’ve had this idea for awhile now and its been loosely discussed on the forum. There is already a feature request for alternative primary identifiers, but nothing official for a secondary identifier so here it goes- I am proposing a secondary user ID alongside your primary user ID (phone number). This way you have 2 ID’s, your existing phone number and a secondary ID. The secondary identifier can be randomly generated by Signal when you first register, for example- Skd4jj3jhh5h8b2hb6lps5s, or…

link_counts.title: Secondary user ID alongside phone number

posts.cooked:
From following the source code development, I also noticed several changes, which seem related and could hint such a feature:

  • Some UUID stuff (additionally to the phone number), which results in a “SMKAddress”, e.g. https://github.com/signalapp/SignalMetadataKit/commit/58e0316701af87e3fb681124ee80d4d800461d08, Fix crash when blocking user's with UUIDs · signalapp/Signal-iOS@55f53dc · GitHub
  • A server-side “Transparent data controller”, which seems to map general strings (i.e. usernames) to phone numbers: Transparent data controller · signalapp/Signal-Server@6ce686a · GitHub

Besides that, the design decision to remove the phone number in the conversation header might also be related.

link_counts.title: Fix crash when blocking user's with UUIDs · signalapp/Signal-iOS@55f53dc · GitHub

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
@RiseT we had agreed in a group chat not to post on the forum and let the devs announce it themselfs when they are ready, to avoid speculation and to not have it be nessesary to hide all the commits and strings until the last possible moment.

Since people are going to search for information now let me share wgat it might mean for users:
It is not clear when this will be introduced, but the Android and Desktop apps and the support center are not ready yet. Any Signal user can optionally make a usernane (bit doesn’t have to make one). The username always starts with an @ followed by a minimum of 4 caracters and can contain only a-z, 0-9 and underscore (I forgot if hyphens are supported). It is unclear if uppercase will be allowed in any way. Only one user can use a username at the time (they are unique) and it seems to be a first come first get.
Your profile name and username are seperate things.

One important thing is unclear: will users who have your phone number also see your username? If that is the case than you can’t share your username anywhere online because your family members who have your phonenumber will be able to look up your username and find out about your on-line activities. Anonimity is not guaranteed if other users can link your username to your phonenumber.
There is also no text string informing users who can see their username, while that is a crucial piece of awarenes a user must have.

Of course all of this is subject to change before release.

Meteor0id:

Anonimity is not guaranteed if other users can link your username to your phonenumber.

Just the fact that you are searchable (possible to add you as a contact) makes anonimity a logical impossibility. Sooner rather than later, someone knows someone who knows someone that knows your handle (or a phone number).

Unless everyone takes a vow of silence, it is impossible to stay anonymous.

That said, usernames make it harder, but not impossible. Anything that makes surveillance really hard is a good thing.

Meteor0id:

we had agreed on our chat not to post on the forum

Who is “we”? And what chat? Don’t know anything about this. I’ve just found out about this feature today by myself. Sorry if I’ve spoiled some surprise.

PS: Don’t know if it makes any sense to delete this now, or if that would be rather silly.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
@RiseT nah of course you don’t have to remove this or such. If it was a secret it wouldn’t have been offered for translation. I just meant that if we always rush to announce whatever we read in the strings offered for translation, devs might feel a pressure to only offer those strings when the feature us almost ready for release, which shortens the time we have to accurately make translations and give feedback. It’s not a big deal just saying.

Here is a concern about this feature:

Usernames can add some amount of anonymity because you can choose which person can find you under which name. Unfortunately that is far less effective if you have only one username, and if you can’t create a new username to share with some new contact, without losing the username you are already using with someone else.
A username is like an alias, but if you can’t freely create new aliases, you will eventually be know as the person with this username.

Reddit for example allows you to make many accounts, allowing users to chat about all kinds of topics without being cross-recognized as the same person.

In Signal we will probably be able to change our username, bit that means we will lose contact with those who already chat with us over our current username, or he will get informed about your new username, wich renders changing it poitless for anonimity purposes.

If you can’t change your username without losing contacts, if your people who have your number can see your current username, usernames will suffer a very similar problem as phone numbers: your usernane is associated with you and you can’t really keep contacts seperated from your identity.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
RiseT:

Don’t know if it makes any sense to delete this now

Anticipation is the highest form of joy. I remember it was similar with sealed sender too.

posts.name: Jay Patel
posts.cooked: Amazing news … Finallyyyy

@Meteor0id

In theory (not set in stone), I take it this means that phone numbers will still be the only way to securely register an account (and to possibly limit spam), but that user names will allow people to pass along a secondary ID so that they don’t need to give away their phone number to other people if they don’t want to. Obviously I am making assumptions here, but the thought-process seems to make sense. Am I off base here?

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Yes there are strong indications that you cannot use signal without registering with your phone number. But I think that makes perfect sense (as you say also to limit spam).

The concern I raised however is that the username might only be a secondary ID, but not an ID you can easily change often, and not a tertiary ID or further.

  1. If you post your username on a public forum, anyone who knows your phone number (your whole family) can also see your username and can find your username using a search engine and find out what forums you are active on.
  2. You probably also can’t have multiple usernames at the same time, so you can’t chat with two people without a chance they find out they have been talking to the same person.
  3. Finally, if you want to change your username, it isn’t clear if your current chat partners will lose contact with you or will be informed of your new username. Either way it means your options are limited. You can’t simply initialize new chats under a different name.

Unless the issues I mention above will also be addressed, usernames are only a rather small addition to your privacy. You still won’t have the freedom to post your username online if you value anonymity. You still can’t chat with multiple users without a risk of them finding out they are chatting with the same person. The only addition they will certainly make is that contacts do not have to know your phone number. As long as no one ever reveals which phone number belongs with your username, you are safe, but if one person connects name and number, your ONLY username and thus all your chats under that username are compromised.

Meteor0id:

Reddit for example allows you to make many accounts, allowing users to chat about all kinds of topics without being cross-recognized as the same person.

I find it hard to believe that it is effective. Browser fingerprinting is a real thing, another one is IP records, also it is probably futile to use the same smartphone with many Reddit accounts, because Reddit app probably gets GoogleID or even IMEI of the device. So any further accounts are probably “linkable” to the originator and they can assume all of those accounts are from one person. Reddit app probably sends some data to Facebook like majority of Android apps, you being on (or not) Facebook or have not linked a Facebook account with the app does not matter.
Now, if you’re using PC only…if you use a VPN, you will most definitely have to provide an email for that account which is another point of “anonymity failure”, because then you have to leave IP on that email address or battle with reCaptcha, if you use VPN to register a mail.

I think it is not easy nor straightforward to have many different “anonymous” accounts and Reddit not asking (most of the time) for any emails is more or less a false sense of anonimity. Some users even reported that they got locked out of their accounts “for suspicious activity” and had to confirm email or change password.

Meteor0id:

If you can’t change your username without losing contacts, if your people who have your number can see your current username, usernames will suffer a very similar problem as phone numbers: your usernane is associated with you and you can’t really keep contacts seperated from your identity.

Staying anonymous with a username while enjoying a social circle is a logical impossibility.

Anonymity can be achieved only on 8chan type of messaging boards i.e. messaging boards that are built to provide and guarantee anonymity.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
IntentionalTypo:

Staying anonymous with a username while enjoying a social circle is a logical impossibility.

Anonymity can be achieved only on 8chan type of messaging boards i.e. messaging boards that are built to provide and guarantee anonymity.

Reddit and 8-chan can do it, and proof that it offers more freedom to post whatever you feel like. For an online forum that sometimes results in some scary public statements, but for a messaging app it might be less scary because nothing is public, and it might actually be more important to offer such freedom to switch usernames and share thoughts under different aliases.

IntentionalTypo:

Browser fingerprinting is a real thing, another one is IP records

That only adds to the importance of segmenting my conversations over different usernames. If someone connects an IP-addres or fingerprint to my username, I rather not have that relate to all my conversations, but keep that contained to only that one username which I mentioned online.

Say I start chatting on Reddit, and I decide to PM my Signal username to someone. That might seem harmless, but from that point forward a Reddit administrator can connect my username to my Reddit account (and anything related to it), my IP-addres and my browser fingerprint. That username is now partially compromised. I can still use it for many things, but not to communicate with Snowden about his most recent revelations, because I am leaving a trail of metadata now which can be uncovered using a subpoena.

Reddit accounts are not really anonymous, but Signal usernames could actaully get quite close.

It would be nice if we could have say, 3 usernames at a time. We could delete ones any time we like, but they get permanently burned. However, if they’re connected to the phone number that becomes a problem when a person switches numbers.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Hormesis:

We could delete ones any time we like, but they get permanently burned.

This will come back to bite some users. There has to be some rate-limit on the number of usernames you can get, to avoid many of them getting permanently burned (have a use history). Yet to only give users one opportunity to pick a name and that’s it, you’re stuck with it, would also not work well. some users might pick a name they later regret, and thus they need an option to change it in order for them to feel free to use Signal with their contacts.

Another way to go is to release used usernames after some time and ignore usage history completely. that also opens up positive deniability that you where the one using a certain username at a certain time. It could be that the username was someone elses at that time.

Hormesis:

However, if they’re connected to the phone number that becomes a problem when a person switches numbers.

Backup files can probably help you reacquire your username, depending on how this is set up server side. There is a lot unknown still about what information will be stored on the server. Hopefully even Signal won’t be able to tell who used which username at what time.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: This commits https://github.com/signalapp/SignalMetadataKit/commit/58e0316701af87e3fb681124ee80d4d800461d08 seems to imply it is possible to have a username but not a phonenumber. But we can’t know for certain how this will be released of course.

Sorry to get late in debate and replying to a lot of messages. It may get TLDR quickly. ;)

Meteor0id:

Any Signal user can optionally make a usernane [..] The username always starts with an @ followed by a minimum of 4 caracters […]. Only one user can use a username at the time […].

If we are speculating… usernames may also be used only internally for your contacts only.

Meteor0id:

One important thing is unclear: will users who have your phone number also see your username?

If there are two separate identities like phone number as primary ID and some form of secondary ID, then there is another question. When you start call or text which identity is going to be used? Can there be set to use some default identity like phone number or secondary ID? Will there be a dialog to always ask to confirm which identity you would like to use primary or secondary?

If using two identities (primary and secondary) we are getting swimming into anonymity pool. In this case protesters from repressing governments using IDs in wrong way (like primary ID instead of secondary ID) they can get imprison or even executed. This is not small thing, it has to be implemented carefully. Zero mistake for users.

Meteor0id:

A username is like an alias, but if you can’t freely create new aliases, you will eventually be know as the person with this username.

This may not be completely useless. It for sure would not be anonymous anymore, but there are the cases when you know the person and you don’t want to reveal the phone number. Like I have been working in my current job with other company members. I don’t want to reveal my phone numbers to them, but I do want to know to whom am I speaking/texting with. Anonymity not required, only non-phone is requested.

Meteor0id:

If you can’t change your username without losing contacts […]

There is another thing. If there are ephemeral usernames and you decide to delete one of username, what happens with contacts that have your old username? All of them are going to be sending messages/calls to black hole. Signal severs may get flooded with never reaching users.

p4nci:

Anticipation is the highest form of joy. I remember it was similar with sealed sender too.

Exactly. But we are now so much guessing that it would help tip or two to get to more accurate direction. We currently do not know if there is going to be non-phone ID as primary ID or is there going to be implemented as secondary ID alongside with phone-number ID. This are two completely separate topics. If first one is used, then a lot of talk in this thread is obsolete immediately.

Depths:

In theory […] I take it this means that phone numbers will still be the only way to securely register an account […].

We just don’t know, we are speculating a lot. This may be thrilling times to anticipate in Signal debate, but a lot of speculations may mean a lot junk in between.

Meteor0id:

there […] are strong indications that you cannot use signal without registering with your phone

Strong is a strong word. ;)

Meteor0id:

The concern I raised however is that the username might only be a secondary ID, but not an ID you can easily change often

There may be some process to auto-generate IDs like some hashes from phone number with salt added. In this case user-IDs would be unique, but extremely hard to reverse. IDs would not be user friendly, more like TOR addresses.

Hormesis:

However, if they’re connected to the phone number that becomes a problem when a person switches numbers.

There could be a process of unlinking secondary ID from old phone number and re-linking secondary ID with new phone number.

But this actually takes as to another problem. If someone registers secondary ID with first phone number, then unlinks secondary ID, but does not yet link secondary ID to new phone number. Now what happens if some other user completely unknown to us independently creates exactly the same secondary ID we just used, before we relink to new phone number. All the secret messages from our anonymous contacts will get in wrong hands. This may be devastating for protesters from repressive regimes.

Meteor0id:

There has to be some rate-limit on the number of usernames you can get, to avoid many of them getting permanently burned […]

And we prefer to be generated on Signal client site. If it is on Signal server site (Signal server controls how many user IDs one primary phone number has), then some additional metadata is revealed to the server (I don’t like it and OWS probably also not). If it is generated on Signal client, because code is open-source, someone knowledgeable can change rate limit.

Meteor0id:

This commits […] seems to imply it is possible to have a username but not a phonenumber.

There can be two primary paths:

  • non-phone numbers as primary identifiers,
  • secondary ID associated to primary phone number ID.

If first option is used, then we have a problem how to confirm identity when registering to not get into spam swamp. Confirmation using emails or something.

If second option is used, we already see in this thread how many challenges are we facing already, but we haven’t scratched the surface yet.

In my humble opinion there will be most probably non-phone number primary ID which is way easier to implement. But I could be wrong. I would for sure like to see temporally volatile unlimited thrown away secondary user IDs. But this is probably way more difficult to implement.

OK, now we need to seat back and think for a moment like a business man. What is the purpose and target Signal audience? Answer, general Joe and Jane to prevent massive government and corporate surveillance. Now to non-phone ID, what additional audience (customers in business language) are we trying to obtain? Whistle-blowers, protesters, freedom fighters…? All this are minorities in user base. From business point of view adding any other feature widespread messengers are having is more in the business plan to achieve goal of attracting new users.

shellSignal:

think for a moment like a business man

“To arrange a tutoring session, contact me securely on @super-duper-tutoring-services on Signal”

I like it already

posts.name: kt
posts.cooked:
I can’t wait any longer for this feature.
I don’t want to display my phone number anymore…

Does anyone know when can we get hands on this feature?

I would like to have anonymous accounts which does not require a phone number to sign up and to have multiple accounts so that way I can have my phone number as an account and when people start messaging me with my phone number account I can send them my anonymous signal username account and use that instead.

The problem with phone numbers is privacy,

accepted_answer.name: Salt
accepted_answer.excerpt:
Signal Messenger

Keep your phone number private with Signal usernames

Signal’s mission and sole focus is private communication. For years, Signal has kept your messages private, your profile information (like your name and profile photo) private, your contacts private, and your groups private – among much else. Now...
